title: Index Sort
problem_statement:
Index Sort

Problem Description

You are given an array A of size N, which contains a permutation of the numbers from 1 to N. To sort the array in ascending order, you must perform the following operations:

  • Choose an integer K from the range [1, N].
  • Select two different indices i and j (both not equal to K) and swap the elements at those indices.
  • You can perform this swap operation multiple times, but K remains fixed throughout the sorting process.

Your task is to find and return an integer value, representing the count of distinct values of K from 1 to N that allow you to transform the given array into sorted order using the above operations.

Note: Assume 1-based indexing.

Input Specification

input1: An integer value N, representing size of the array A.

input2: An integer array A.

Output Specification

Return an integer value, representing the count of distinct values of K from 1 to N that allow you to transform the given array into sorted order using the above operations.

Examples

Example 1:

Input:
input1: 6
input2: [2,3,5,4,1,6]
Output: 2

Explanation:

The given array is (2,3,5,4,1,6).

If we choose K = 4, we can perform the following swaps to sort the array:

  • Swap the elements at indices 1 and 5: (1,3,5,4,2,6)
  • Swap the elements at indices 2 and 5: (1,2,5,4,3,6)
  • Swap the elements at indices 3 and 5: (1,2,3,4,5,6)

If we choose K = 6, we can perform the following swaps to sort the array:

  • Swap the elements at indices 1 and 5: (1,3,5,4,2,6)
  • Swap the elements at indices 2 and 5: (1,2,5,4,3,6)
  • Swap the elements at indices 3 and 5: (1,2,3,4,5,6)

After these swaps, the array gets sorted in increasing order. There are only two valid choices for K, which are 4 and 6, which allow us to sort the array using swaps. Hence 2 is returned as the output.

Example 2:

Input:
input1: 4
input2: [1,2,3,4]
Output: 4

Explanation:

In this example, the given array (1, 2, 3, 4) is already sorted in increasing order. Since there are no elements out of place, we can choose any value of K from 1 to 4 and the array remains sorted. Hence 4 is returned as the output.

#include <stdio.h>
#include <string.h>

// Read only region start
// Read only region end
int totalcount(int input1,int input2[])
{

title: Index Sort
problem_statement:
Index Sort

Problem Description

You are given an array A of size N, which contains a permutation of the numbers from 1 to N. To sort the array in ascending order, you must perform the following operations:

  • Choose an integer K from the range [1, N].
  • Select two different indices i and j (both not equal to K) and swap the elements at those indices.
  • You can perform this swap operation multiple times, but K remains fixed throughout the sorting process.

Your task is to find and return an integer value, representing the count of distinct values of K from 1 to N that allow you to transform the given array into sorted order using the above operations.

Note: Assume 1-based indexing.

Input Specification

Input1: An integer value N, representing size of the array A.

Input2: An integer array A.

Output Specification

Return an integer value, representing the count of distinct values of K from 1 to N that allow you to transform the given array into sorted order using the above operations.

Examples

Example 1:

Input:
N = 6
A = [2,3,5,4,1,6]
Output: 2

Explanation: The given array is [2,3,5,4,1,6].

If we choose K = 4, we can perform the following swaps to sort the array:

  • Swap the elements at indices 1 and 5: [1,3,5,4,2,6]
  • Swap the elements at indices 2 and 5: [1,2,5,4,3,6]
  • Swap the elements at indices 3 and 5: [1,2,3,4,5,6]

If we choose K = 6, we can perform the following swaps to sort the array:

  • Swap the elements at indices 1 and 5: [1,3,5,4,2,6]
  • Swap the elements at indices 2 and 5: [1,2,5,4,3,6]
  • Swap the elements at indices 3 and 5: [1,2,3,4,5,6]

After these swaps, the array gets sorted in increasing order. There are only two valid choices for K, which are 4 and 6, which allow us to sort the array using swaps. Hence 2 is returned as the output.

Example 2:

Input:
N = 4
A = [1,2,3,4]
Output: 4

Explanation: In this example, the given array [1, 2, 3, 4] is already sorted in increasing order. Since there are no elements out of place, we can choose any value of K from 1 to 4 and the array remains sorted. Hence 4 is returned as the output.

Constraints

  • Array A contains a permutation of numbers from 1 to N.
  • K is an integer from the range [1, N].
